Text: Break the Box
What's up, Chaz? \n Something bothering you?
Well, I'm in charge of \n training all the new \n recruits...
But there's one trainee \n who hasn't shown up - he \n hasn't even checked in.
Maybe he just overslept?
Say, Kat, would you mind \n undertaking the training \n instead?
Why me?

I want someone who 
 can give me objective 
 feedback on my 
 training program.
Though I'm sure it'll \n be far too basic for \n someone like you...
Hmm... Training does \n sound kind of boring...
Tell you what, do me \n this favor, and I'll \n treat you to dinner.

Okay, you hooked me! 
 And hey, it's my civic 
 responsibility to help 
 the police, right?
Thank you. \n Okay, let's head over \n to the training site.
Let's begin \n the training.

Please don't use your 
 gravity powers so we can 
 simulate the experience 
 of a normal recruit.
Yeah, no problem!

Just "yes" will do. Now 
 that you're a recruit, 
 you have to act like 
 one.
He's taking this a \n little seriously...
First is training your \n "photographic memory."
This is important for \n building concentration \n and memory skills.
But before we start, \n break that box.
Huh? \n You want me to \n break a box?
Remember the Contents \n of the Picture
I-It exploded!
It's rigged to explode \n if you make a mistake.

In a real investigation, 
 mistakes can be 
 the difference between 
 life and death.

I need recruits to 
 understand that, not 
 just with their mind, 
 but with their body.
But that's dangerous!
I've ensured the \n gunpowder isn't enough \n to kill anyone.

And if you want to avoid 
 the pain, all you have 
 to do is answer 
 correctly.
This training program \n is a little extreme...
Hold k : Put Away the Picture and Answer the Question
Alright, let's begin \n training your \n photographic memory.
I'll hand you a picture. \n Try to remember \n everything about it.
When you're ready, let \n me know, and I'll ask \n you a few questions.
If you can answer three \n in a row, you pass the \n test.
Chaz: \n We're in the middle of training, you can't leave now.

Take another good look 
 at the picture and 
 remember everything 
 about it.
Break the Box that Represents \n the Correct Answer
Wrong.
Pay attention to the \n order of the people in \n the picture.
Let's try again.
Here's the first \n question.
Who was on the \n rightmost side of \n the picture?
Here's the first \n question.
Who was second \n from the right \n in the picture?
Here's the first \n question.
Who was second \n from the left \n in the picture?
Here's the first \n question.
Who was on the \n leftmost side of \n the picture?
Wrong.
Pay attention to the \n positioning of the \n people in the picture.
Let's try again.
Now for the second \n question.
Who was closest to the \n front in the picture?
Now for the second \n question.
Who was furthest away \n in the picture?
Now for the second \n question.
Who was second closest \n to the front in the \n picture?
Now for the second \n question.
Who was second closest \n to the back in the \n picture?
Wrong.
Pay attention to what \n the people are doing.
Let's try again.
And now the third and \n final question.
Who was sitting in the \n picture?
And now the third and \n final question.
Who was folding their \n arms in the picture?
And now the third and \n final question.
Who was clapping in the \n picture?
And now the third and \n final question.
Who was raising their \n left hand in the \n picture?
You answered everything \n correctly!
Awesome, I passed!
Alright, let's move on \n to the next training \n challenge.
Chaz, don't be in such a \n rush, where's my praise \n for doing a good job?
Training is part of the \n job. Passing the test \n is a requirement.
Motivation should \n be an important \n part of the job too...
Next up...

We need to train your 
 "situational awareness" 
 to help with controlling 
 criminals.
A little fighting, eh? \n I should ace this part!

My fellow officers will 
 be playing the part of 
 some criminals you need 
 to knock out.
But before that, \n I need you to \n break that box.
Uh-oh... \n Another box?
Yes, please.
I knew it!
More boxes like that \n one will be scattered \n across the field.

You're to assume 
 they're citizens. 
 Avoid collateral 
 damage.
Fine, but why do \n the citizens have \n to explode!?

It's a police officer's 
 first duty to protect 
 citizens. It's important 
 to remember that.
Not just with the mind, \n but with the body.
Chaz is going a little \n overboard. I feel bad \n for his trainees.
Let's begin the \n situational awareness \n training.
Take out the bad guys \n without hurting the \n civilian boxes.
If you destroy three or \n more boxes...
Or if you leave the \n fighting area, you fail.
You failed. Let's try \n that again.
Please be more \n careful around the \n citizens this time.
You failed to stay \n within the \n fighting area.
I did it! They're all \n knocked out cold!
Consider that a \n practice round.
The next fight is \n the real deal.
Okay...
You broke the boxes, \n try it again.
Agh! Those boxes just \n keep getting in the way.
Those "boxes" are the \n civilians you're \n supposed to protect.
You left the designated \n area, try it again.
There aren't any \n "designated areas" \n in a real fight...
There, that's all of \n 'em. Am I done now?
No, the next fight is \n the real deal.
Wait!? You just said \n that about the last \n fight!

An officer must be ready 
 to be pushed to the 
 limit and then pushed 
 some more.
That's how we grow.
It's just like \n weight training.
In other words, \n painful...
You broke the boxes, \n try it again.
Is it really \n necessary for the \n citizens to explode?

Yes, that's how the 
 training exercise was 
 designed, so we do it 
 by the book.
You left the designated \n area, try it again.
Isn't taking down the \n bad guys the only thing \n that's important?
You've passed with \n flying colors, Kat.
I-I did?
Finally, some praise \n after all this time!
Okay, let's move to \n the site for the \n next lesson.
We're here to train your \n "character judgment" \n skills.

The goal is to train 
 your attentiveness and 
 assessment skills to 
 aid in crime prevention.
That's fine, but I'm not \n breaking any more boxes.
How many times do I have \n to tell you, enough with \n the explosions!

If you fail to spot the 
 suspect, the box will 
 explode as it did just 
 now.

As an officer, if you 
 don't stop crime before 
 it starts, an innocent 
 citizen gets hurt.

Officers have to 
 understand that, not 
 just with their minds, 
 but with their bodies.
I'm starting to think \n Chaz just likes \n explosions...
Let's begin the \n character judgment \n training.
Police officers playing \n suspicious people are \n coming this way.

Stand on that box and 
 capture them with your 
 camera before it's too 
 late.
If you can get a clear \n picture of their face, \n you're fine.
But if the suspect gets \n close to you, you fail.
You failed. \n Let's try that again.
Stay calm, and watch the \n suspect's movements.
I got the picture! \n That was pretty \n straightforward.
That's because it was \n practice, and there was \n only one criminal.
Oh...
Next, there'll be two. \n Get both of their \n pictures.
You failed. \n Let's try that again.
Pay close attention and \n make sure you grab both \n of them on film.
You passed.
Not bad, huh?
Next, there \n will be four.
What!? Now they're \n growing exponentially?
Don't let any of them \n slip through. Capture \n them all on film.
You failed. \n Let's try that again.
Be aware of your \n surroundings, and don't \n let them slip by.
Why are you taking \n a picture of me?
We're in the middle of \n training, please take it \n seriously.
Seriously, got it...
You pass. You got all of \n their pictures.
Hehe. Does this mean \n I've passed all your \n tests?

The training must be too 
 easy. I need to step it 
 up to unlock an 
 officer's potential.
Wha-!?
Oh, nothing. Your \n training's not done-
I'm done with this! \n No more training, \n no more explosions!
I think I've been nice \n until now, but it's time \n I spoke my mind.
You're too obsessed with \n all this and too hard on \n your trainees.

That trainee who didn't 
 show up had the right 
 idea if he values his 
 life!

And what's with that 
 training box shaking 
 right there... Another 
 explosion?
I didn't rig it with \n explosives...
If it wasn't you, \n then...
Ugh...
There was a person \n inside!
You're that trainee \n who didn't show up!
Are you okay? \n What happened?
Ugh...
Training's over. Kat, \n get this man to a \n hospital, quick.
The person we found in the box was the \n police rookie I was standing in for.
He was admitted to the hospital with serious injuries, \n but we still have no idea how he ended up in the box. \n And in all the excitement, Chaz forgot to treat me to dinner.
Broken Boxes

I can't afford to break any more boxes.
